history.content:
Financial technology, financial engineering, and quantitative research are all completely different fields:

  1. Financial technology ("fintech") generally refers to a class of companies that facilitate transactions, payments, and services (e.g. Stripe, PayPal).
  2. Financial engineering is constructing pricing models for exotic derivatives or securities that a bank might offer to its clients (e.g. pricing quant at Goldman).
  3. Quantitative research can be broadly thought of as using statistical models to gain some sort of "edge" or alpha for a firm above that of the relevant index (e.g. QR at Two Sigma).

If you want to work for (1), generic SWE classes are helpful as you won't touch the finance aspect. No major will teach you (2) and you should look into a Masters for Financial Engineering if you're set on that path. If you want to work for (3), econ/IEOR is generally useless - taking stats/ML/probability courses are a much better option. 

Taking relevant classes if they align with your goals is good. Doing another major for the sake of doing another major is bad - you don't get points for effort, you get points for being exceptional at whatever your interests are.

  2. Financial engineering is constructing pricing models for exotic derivatives or securities that a bank might offer to its clients (e.g. pricing quant at Goldman).
  3. Quantitative research can be broadly thought of as using statistical models to gain some sort of "edge" or alpha for a firm above that of the relevant index (e.g. QR at Two Sigma).

If you want to work for (1), generic SWE classes are helpful as you won't touch the finance aspect. No major will teach you (2) and you should look into a Masters for Financial Engineering if you're set on that path. If you want to work for (3), taking stats/ML/probability courses are useful. 

Taking relevant classes if they align with your goals is good. Doing another major for the sake of doing another major is bad - you don't get points for effort, you get points for being exceptional at whatever your interests are.

I am an intended cs, it's my second semester at cal. I am interested in financial technology/engineering; so I plan to declare another major except cs. Which double major will be more suitable for these specialities - cs/econ(finance) or cs/industrial engineering and operations research?

thanks!
history.subject: Quant/fintech/financial engineering
